title: Besides soundproofing, what are good acoustic materials for recording music? - Quora

response.answer_text: Honestly, most soundproofing tends to be terrible as an acoustic medium for recording. Its job is to prevent transmission of sound in or out of a room, but it doesn’t really control sound within the room much. For good recording and mixing, there are really two things you’re talking about: AbsorptionA lot of folks think that absorbers and soundproofing are the same thing. They aren’t, although there’s some overlap. An absorber, like rockwool or OC703 or Auralex or whatnot, is designed to absorb and control certain frequencies. It doesn’t stop all sound or block all sound, but it prevents reflections within a space. There are many different kinds. Rigid fiberglass, mineral fabrics, closed-cell foams, etc. And there’s the old stanbdby, eggcrate foam, which is downright AWFUL and terribly misleading - so don’t use that.DiffusionThis one doesn’t get talked about as much, but it’s the secret weapon of a lot of studios. Diffusers are solid assemblies - usually wood or plastic - that reflect and scatter sound waves in certain mathematically-predictable patterns. They’re useful for breaking up standing waves in a space and ultimately make the space sound “bigger” than it is. They tend not to be cheap, but they can also be DIY’ed with a bit of lumber and some wood glue. There are also some manufacturers who make diffuser tiles for drop ceilings etc - I’m not sure of the efficacy of those but they’re probably better than nothing.There are some good discussions online regarding DIY room treatment. You can hack together a pretty decent broadband absorber using some cheap fabric and some panels of rockwool for only a few bucks (more if you want them to look nice). I’m currently attempting to build a lightweight diffuser myself - all the previous ones I’ve built from plans have been wood and incredibly heavy so I’m in the process of trying to figure out how to reduce the weight.
